page.title: 10CLEEVE HILL
page.content: MOST OF THE GROUND IS MOORLAND.GORSE BUSHES AND HEATHER ARE SCATTERED AROUND .THERE ARE A FEW WILD FLOWERS, PARTICULARY COWSLIPS. THE HIGHEST POINT ON CLEEVE COMMON IS THE TRIG STATION WHICH IS AT 315.5 METRES. THERE ARE SPECTACULAR VIEWS IN ALL DIRECTIONS. YOU CAN SEE THE BLACK MOUNTAINS 77 MILES AWAY ON A CLEAR DAY.YOU CAN ALSO SEE SUDELEY CASTLE AND MANY OTHER PLACES FROM HERE. BELOW THIS POINT YOU CAN SEE THE OUTSKIRTS OF WOODMANCOTE AND PART OF GLOUCESTER. BENS TUMP,AN ANCIENT BURIAL MOUND,AND THE ANCIENT RING SETTLEMENT ARE WITHIN THE AREA. THERE ARE QUITE A NUMBER OF QUARRYS WHERE LIMESTONE USED TO BE DUG. NON CONIFEROUS TREES AT THE BOTTOM OF THE HILL FORM A WOOD WITH A SPRING NOT FAR FROM IT.THE WOODMANCOTE DEVELOPMENT NESTLES BENEATH THE HILL.
